sentence.text: The patient is a male born on September 12, 2017 from a Chinese family.
His parents were not consanguineously married and were healthy.
Shortly after birth, the proband had repeat cardiac and respiratory arrests after crying and was diagnosed with ventricular septal defect (VSD) and pulmonary hypertension at a local hospital.

After hospitalization in the cardiothoracic surgery department at Children's Hospital of Fudan University in March 2018, the proband was found to have special facial features, including golden hair, midface dysplasia, depressed nasal bridge, and gray irides (Figure 1a,b).
We also found the proband had short and broad hands with a single transverse palmar crease, while no significant abnormalities in the feet were found (Figure 1c,e).
Then, we retrospected his medical history and improved the relevant examinations.
Nasopharyngeal CT indicated the patient exhibits nasal septal dysplasia (Figure 1g).
Chest and abdomen radiograph showed the patient had bronchopneumonia (Figure 1h).
VSD, pulmonary hypertension, and right ventricular enlargement were also confirmed by echocardiogram and electrocardiogram examination of the proband (Figure 1f,i).

Endocrinological findings showed that the free thyroxin (FT4) level was decreased, but free triiodothyronine (FT3) and TSH values were normal, which did not reveal the characteristic TSH hormone resistance.
Increased serum phosphorus and decreased phosphaturia may suggest decreased PTH secretion or PTH resistance.
Elevated lactate dehydrogenase and creatine kinase isoenzyme MB (CK-MB) suggest that the patient may have myocardial injury.
The patient had a height of 63â€‰cm and weight of 7.4 kg, possessing a normal body mass index of 18.6, which is in accordance with normal human growth factor levels (Table 1).
Immunological examinations showed no obvious abnormalities for the patient in addition to CD3+, CD19+, and CD45+ absolute counts (Table S1).
